awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Multiscale Approach to Understand Outflows During High-Mass Star Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Most stars in the Milky Way Galaxy are like our Sun, but there are also stars with masses up to 100 times higher. These high-mass stars output enormous amounts of energy and live only for a few million years before ending their life as a supernova. A major challenge in astrophysics is to understand how these stars are formed. The investigators will use the National Science Foundation's large radio telescopes to observe young high-mass stars, which are still growing as surrounding matter falls onto them. During this process some of the matter is expelled in the form of jets and outflows of hot gas. To make progress in our scientific understanding of high-mass star formation, the next step is understanding the flow of material near these stars. A systematic study of outflows and jets is thus urgently needed. With these radio telescopes, the investigators will chart the flow of matter near these stars. Specifically, the investigators will make new observations every few months and map the motion of the clumps of material over time. The project is a collaboration between a primarily Hispanic serving university in New Mexico and a primarily undergraduate institution in rural Illinois. Student involvement in the planned observations provide hands-on STEM education on a variety of educational levels. Students will also take part in institutional interchanges and public outreach activities lead by the principal investigators. This project will thereby promote the participation of women and minorities in science.

Ionized jets and molecular outflows are commonly present in high-mass proto-stars. This project will carry out a multiscale observational study which addresses fundamental unanswered questions on the physics of the mass outflows. The goals of the project are 1) to connect the ionized jets to the large scale molecular flows with high quality measurements of the momentum rates, 2) to directly measure the ionized jet motion via proper motion and spectral line observations, and 3) to use water and methanol maser observations to study the jet launching mechanism, as well as the momentum transfer between ionized and molecular gas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stars with masses exceeding 8 times that of the Sun are important for nearly every branch of Astronomy due to their prodigious energy output. For this reason understanding how they form is of critical importance. We know that the formation of these high mass stars occur in dense condensations of molecular clouds, where gravity causes a collapse and hence mass accumulation, to form the star. Surprisingly, early observations of such objects found bipolar mass outflows, i.e. matter which the star ejects during the formation process. At the present time it has become clear that mass outflow is a critical component of the formation process, and our projects goal was to improve our understanding of the role of mass outflows in the formation of a high mass star.

To make progress towards this goal one first needs to identify suitable high mass protostars. We have achieved this goal using VLA continuum obervations at 6 and 1.3 cm wavelengths to search for ionized jet sources, and then examined closer a large candidate list with further VLA observations of high angular resolution continuum, as well as SiO molecular lines. We also created a computer program which is able to mine existing datasets to find new spectral line probes for mass outflows fro high mass stars. This process resulted in a sample of about 13 bona fide high mass protostars, which we then began to study in detail. Some noteworthy results are 1) a CO spectral line study of one protostar, where we obtained detailed maps showing a narrow high velocity component together with a wider angle component, 2) the discovery of an extremely wide OH molecular absorption line, coincident with a extremely wide Hydrogen line, possibly indicating the transition between the ionized amd molecular outflow phases, and 3) the measurement of the magnetic field in outflows shocks. Many more details of our work are reported in 9 articles in professional astronomical journals.

Our project also provided many opportunities for broader impact activities. Participants ranged from the general public, K-12 students to undergraduate, MS level and PhD students. Activities included public talks, and outreach events where hands-on activities for the students were created, and made available. At the university level 13 undergraduate students were mentored and introduced to research. These activities provided oppurtunities to students from rural America (western Illinois) and minority students from the Chicago area, as well as to a predominately Hispanic population in central New Mexico. Several MS and PhD students played key roles in the research described above, and all our publications include student authors. Finally, the work on our research project will result in a PhD degree for a hispanic female student (expected 2024).
